Question 2:
Machine: MacBook Pro Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-7360U CPU @ 2.30GHz
2.1 Experiment with Different Loop Arrangements

The best performance was achieved with the arrangment 2, whose innermost loop iterates through each row in a, middle loop iterates each column in a, and outermost loop iterates through column in c. Because the matrices are stored in column major order, it takes advantage of the fast memory by accessing the matrix a and c column by column. 

Loop arrangement 1: m, n, k
Dimension       Time    Gflop/s       GB/s        Error
        16   0.698929   2.861524  45.784378 0.000000e+00
        64   1.073026   1.864035  29.824568 0.000000e+00

2.2 Blocking Scheme

Based on my experiments' results, it seems that with a block size of 48 the program achieved the best performance, flop rate of 17 Gflop/s and bandwidth of 280 GB/s, though the performance was very close when block size varies from 48 to 100. But all performances stayed the same no matter how large the matrix was.

Block size = 4:                                          
 Dimension       Time    Gflop/s       GB/s        Error
         4   0.818697   2.442905  39.086484 0.000000e+00
